lines.text: Enter CHARMIAN, IRAS, ALEXAS, and a Soothsayer

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Lord Alexas, sweet Alexas, most any thing Alexas, almost most absolute Alexas, wheres the soothsayer that you praised so to the queen O, that I knew this husband, which, you say, must charge his horns with garlands!

lines.speaker: alexas
lines.text: Soothsayer!

lines.speaker: soothsayer
lines.text: Your will

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Is this the man Ist you, sir, that know things

lines.speaker: soothsayer
lines.text: In natures infinite book of secrecy A little I can read.

lines.speaker: alexas
lines.text: Show him your hand.
Enter DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Bring in the banquet quickly wine enough Cleopatras health to drink.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Good sir, give me good fortune.

lines.speaker: soothsayer
lines.text: I make not, but foresee.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Pray, then, foresee me one.

lines.speaker: soothsayer
lines.text: You shall be yet far fairer than you are.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: He means in flesh.

lines.speaker: iras
lines.text: No, you shall paint when you are old.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Wrinkles forbid!

lines.speaker: alexas
lines.text: Vex not his prescience be attentive.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Hush!

lines.speaker: soothsayer
lines.text: You shall be more beloving than beloved.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: I had rather heat my liver with drinking.

lines.speaker: alexas
lines.text: Nay, hear him.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Good now, some excellent fortune! Let me be married to three kings in a forenoon, and widow them all: let me have a child at fifty, to whom Herod of Jewry may do homage: find me to marry me with Octavius Caesar, and companion me with my mistress.

lines.speaker: soothsayer
lines.text: You shall outlive the lady whom you serve.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: O excellent! I love long life better than figs.

lines.speaker: soothsayer
lines.text: You have seen and proved a fairer former fortune Than that which is to approach.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Then belike my children shall have no names: prithee, how many boys and wenches must I have

lines.speaker: soothsayer
lines.text: If every of your wishes had a womb. And fertile every wish, a million.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Out, fool! I forgive thee for a witch.

lines.speaker: alexas
lines.text: You think none but your sheets are privy to your wishes.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Nay, come, tell Iras hers.

lines.speaker: alexas
lines.text: Well know all our fortunes.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Mine, and most of our fortunes, tonight, shall bedrunk to bed.

lines.speaker: iras
lines.text: Theres a palm presages chastity, if nothing else.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Een as the oerflowing Nilus presageth famine.

lines.speaker: iras
lines.text: Go, you wild bedfellow, you cannot soothsay.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Nay, if an oily palm be not a fruitful prognostication, I cannot scratch mine ear. Prithee, tell her but a workyday fortune.

lines.speaker: soothsayer
lines.text: Your fortunes are alike.

lines.speaker: iras
lines.text: But how, but how give me particulars.

lines.speaker: soothsayer
lines.text: I have said.

lines.speaker: iras
lines.text: Am I not an inch of fortune better than she

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Well, if you were but an inch of fortune better than I, where would you choose it

lines.speaker: iras
lines.text: Not in my husbands nose.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Our worser thoughts heavens mend! Alexas,come, his fortune, his fortune! O, let him marry a woman that cannot go, sweet Isis, I beseech thee! and let her die too, and give him a worse! and let worst follow worse, till the worst of all follow him laughing to his grave, fiftyfold a cuckold! Good Isis, hear me this prayer, though thou deny me a matter of more weight good Isis, I beseech thee!

lines.speaker: iras
lines.text: Amen. Dear goddess, hear that prayer of the people! for, as it is a heartbreaking to see a handsome man loosewived, so it is a deadly sorrow to behold a foul knave uncuckolded: therefore, dear Isis, keep decorum, and fortune him accordingly!

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Amen.

lines.speaker: alexas
lines.text: Lo, now, if it lay in their hands to make me a cuckold, they would make themselves whores, but theyld dot!

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Hush! here comes Antony.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Not he the queen.
Enter CLEOPATRA

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Saw you my lord

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: No, lady.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Was he not here

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: No, madam.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: He was disposed to mirth but on the sudden A Roman thought hath struck him. Enobarbus!

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Madam

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Seek him, and bring him hither. Wheres Alexas

lines.speaker: alexas
lines.text: Here, at your service. My lord approaches.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: We will not look upon him: go with us.
Exeunt
Enter MARK ANTONY with a Messenger and Attendants

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Fulvia thy wife first came into the field.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Against my brother Lucius

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Ay: But soon that war had end, and the times state Made friends of them, joining their force gainst Caesar Whose better issue in the war, from Italy, Upon the first encounter, drave them.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Well, what worst

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: The nature of bad news infects the teller.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: When it concerns the fool or coward. On: Things that are past are done with me. Tis thus: Who tells me true, though in his tale lie death, I hear him as he flatterd.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Labienus This is stiff newshath, with his Parthian force, Extended Asia from Euphrates His conquering banner shook from Syria To Lydia and to Ionia Whilst

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Antony, thou wouldst say,

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: O, my lord!

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Speak to me home, mince not the general tongue: Name Cleopatra as she is calld in Rome Rail thou in Fulvias phrase and taunt my faults With such full licence as both truth and malice Have power to utter. O, then we bring forth weeds, When our quick minds lie still and our ills told us Is as our earing. Fare thee well awhile.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: At your noble pleasure.
Exit

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: From Sicyon, ho, the news! Speak there!

lines.speaker: first attendant
lines.text: The man from Sicyon,is there such an one

lines.speaker: second attendant
lines.text: He stays upon your will.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Let him appear. These strong Egyptian fetters I must break, Or lose myself in dotage. What are you
Enter another Messenger

lines.speaker: second messenger
lines.text: Fulvia thy wife is dead.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Where died she

lines.speaker: second messenger
lines.text: In Sicyon: Her length of sickness, with what else more serious Importeth thee to know, this bears.
Gives a letter

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Forbear me. Theres a great spirit gone! Thus did I desire it: What our contempt doth often hurl from us, We wish it ours again the present pleasure, By revolution lowering, does become The opposite of itself: shes good, being gone The hand could pluck her back that shoved her on. I must from this enchanting queen break off: Ten thousand harms, more than the ills I know, My idleness doth hatch. How now! Enobarbus!
Exit Second Messenger
Reenter DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Whats your pleasure, sir

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: I must with haste from hence.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Why, then, we kill all our women: we see how mortal an unkindness is to them if they suffer our departure, deaths the word.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: I must be gone.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Under a compelling occasion, let women die it were pity to cast them away for nothing though, between them and a great cause, they should be esteemed nothing. Cleopatra, catching but the least noise of this, dies instantly I have seen her die twenty times upon far poorer moment: I do think there is mettle in death, which commits some loving act upon her, she hath such a celerity in dying.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: She is cunning past mans thought.
Exit ALEXAS

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Alack, sir, no her passions are made of nothing but the finest part of pure love: we cannot call her winds and waters sighs and tears they are greater storms and tempests than almanacs can report: this cannot be cunning in her if it be, she makes a shower of rain as well as Jove.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Would I had never seen her.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: O, sir, you had then left unseen a wonderful piece of work which not to have been blest withal would have discredited your travel.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Fulvia is dead.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Sir

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Fulvia is dead.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Fulvia!

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Dead.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Why, sir, give the gods a thankful sacrifice. When it pleaseth their deities to take the wife of a man from him, it shows to man the tailors of the earth comforting therein, that when old robes are worn out, there are members to make new. If there were no more women but Fulvia, then had you indeed a cut, and the case to be lamented: this grief is crowned with consolation your old smock brings forth a new petticoat: and indeed the tears live in an onion that should water this sorrow.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: The business she hath broached in the state Cannot endure my absence.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: And the business you have broached here cannot be without you especially that of Cleopatras, which wholly depends on your abode.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: No more light answers. Let our officers Have notice what we purpose. I shall break The cause of our expedience to the queen, And get her leave to part. For not alone The death of Fulvia, with more urgent touches, Do strongly speak to us but the letters too Of many our contriving friends in Rome Petition us at home: Sextus Pompeius Hath given the dare to Caesar, and commands The empire of the sea: our slippery people, Whose love is never linkd to the deserver Till his deserts are past, begin to throw Pompey the Great and all his dignities Upon his son who, high in name and power, Higher than both in blood and life, stands up For the main soldier: whose quality, going on, The sides o the world may danger: much is breeding, Which, like the coursers hair, hath yet but life, And not a serpents poison. Say, our pleasure, To such whose place is under us, requires Our quick remove from hence.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: I shall dot.
Exeunt
